Originales de la América Central y América del Sur, concentradas principalmente en las regiones Andinas de Sudamérica del norte y occidental, y la más grande en Brasil, principalmente las regiones costeras. Cattleyas también hay en México, Panamá, Trinidad, Venezuela y Perú.

Cattley, coleccionista de orquídeas muerto en la primera mitad del siglo XIX.Cattleya es un género de entre 50 y 75 especies de orquídeas epífitas. hora existen bellos híbridos que es posible cultivar en un cuarto de estar.Se caracteriza por la presencia de pseudobulbos cilíndricos de varios nodos con hojas gruesas.Planta epífita provista de pseudobulbo que arranca de un tallo rizomatoso, emergiendo del mismo las raíces con las que la orquídea se adhiere a la planta huésped.En el ápice de los pseudobulbos se insertan una o dos hojas sésiles y carnosas.

Humedad ambiental del 70 al 80% de humedad relativo, o más de 20ºC; del 50 al 60%, entre 14 y 18ºC. Esto se puede lograr también en el hogar poniendo las plantas sobre grava parcialmente cubierta con agua.

Scientific or Latin name: Cattleya spp.
Common or vulgar name: Cattleya, Cattleya, Lirio de Mayo, Lirio de San Juan, Sanjuan
Family: Orchidaceae (Orchidaceae).
Source: Originally from Central and South America, concentrated mainly in the Andean regions of northern and western South America, and the largest in Brazil, mainly the coastal regions. Cattleyas are also found in Mexico, Panama, Trinidad, Venezuela and Peru.
Etymology: Generic name dedicated to W. Cattley, an orchid collector who died in the first half of the 19th century. Cattleya is a genus of between 50 and 75 species of epiphytic orchids. Now there are beautiful hybrids that can be grown in a living room. It is characterized by the presence of cylindrical pseudobulbs with several nodes and thick leaves. Epiphytic plant with a pseudobulb that starts from a rhizomatous stem, emerging from it the roots with which the plant grows. orchid adheres to the host plant. One or two sessile, fleshy leaves are inserted at the apex of the pseudobulbs.
Flowers: Racemes of small flowers or large solitary flowers; lip more or less recurved, sometimes furrowed. Flowering throughout the year (depends on the variety). The flowers last about 3 weeks. Most Cattleya are scented.
Longevity: It lives for one to three years indoors, and up to 7 to 10 years in a greenhouse or veranda.
CATTLEYA CULTIVATION Fairly easy growing plant. Very varied in their requirements and demands for cultivation, although they usually need high humidity and high temperatures. Light: Very bright. The suns rays should never reach the plant directly. During growth they also like a lot of light, preferably in the sun, but with protection during the hottest hours of the afternoon. winter and in a place where they receive natural light, both in intensity and duration. It is important that Cattleya undergoes the shortening of the day to flower. If the plants are in a place with artificial light during the winter, which artificially prolongs the duration of the day, there is a risk of preventing its flowering. Therefore, light is one of the most important factors in the cultivation of Cattleyas.
Temperatures: Suitable for interior or temperate greenhouse (minimum 11ºC) as long as it is vaporized regularly. In summer they can be taken outside. The difference in temperature between day and night is essential for the health of cultivated orchids, whether at home or in an orchid garden, 3º to 4ºC of variation between day and night is needed.
Humidity: Environmental humidity 70 to 80% relative humidity, or more than 20ºC; 50 to 60%, between 14 and 18ºC. This can also be achieved at home by placing the plants on gravel partially covered with water. Substratum: Substrates based on processed bark; it can be pure bark, bark with carbon or bark with moss. Any of the three substrates is suitable, although the frequency of irrigation they need changes.
Irrigation: During the vegetative growth of the plant, which is known by the new rootlets that appear in its front part and by the new shoots, watering must be more frequent; but it is limited at the time they go into rest, when the plant has completed its development and flowering. Watering should be done in the form of soft rain so as not to destroy the new shoots.
Subscriber: Soluble fertilizers will be provided at low concentrations every 15 days. The fertilizer must be rich in nitrogen during the formation of pseudobulbs in spring, and then rich in potassium to promote flowering. To make them bloom, a formula rich in phosphorus such as 10-30-20 is recommended, every 4 or 6 applications to generate strong flowers and healthy buds. When it is in active growth the plant needs fertilizer every two weeks, and when it is not in this period once a month.
Pot change: Normally they must be transplanted every 2 or 3 years to renew the substrate or divide the plant, in spring. Transplant into a fairly narrow pot.
Diseases: Do not confuse fungus with normal leaf drop in orchids. If they are the oldest and the new bulbs remain intact, it is normal, on the other hand, if the fall of leaves does not respect the newest and the oldest, immediate measures must be taken because it is a fungus.Excess water and lack of ventilation cause Black Leaf Rot.
Pests: Aphids, thrips, cottony mealybugs and mites.
Multiplication: By division of bushes; make sure that there are at least 3 shoots formed plus at least one other already developing, in order to ensure rooting. If the bush has formed at least six or eight pseudobulbs. A cattleya divided correctly and in the corresponding time, and with a good cultivation, should flower without problems in the following season.
